articles.headline: NASA Targets March 6 Launch for First Crewed Moon Mission in 50 Years
articles.subheadline: Artemis II will send four astronauts farther into space than any human has traveled, circling the Moon's far side
articles.body:
NASA has confirmed a March 6 launch date for the Artemis II mission, which will send four astronauts around the Moon in humanity's deepest venture into space, following a successful fueling test of the massive Space Launch System rocket at Kennedy Space Center in Florida.

The 10-day mission will carry three American astronauts — Reid Wiseman, Victor Glover, and Christina Koch — along with Canadian astronaut Jeremy Hansen on a trajectory around the far side of the Moon, passing between 6,500 and 9,500 kilometers above the lunar surface. It will mark the first crewed lunar voyage since Apollo 17 in 1972, and the crew entered quarantine on Friday in preparation. "Every night I look up at the Moon and I see it and I get real excited because I can feel she's calling us and we're ready," said NASA's Lori Glaze at a press conference announcing the date.

The launch confirmation came after a successful "wet dress rehearsal" — a full fueling and countdown simulation — on the agency's second attempt. An earlier rehearsal in early February was cut short by a hydrogen fuel leak at the launch pad, but Glaze said issues with seals and filters had been resolved. The 98-meter-tall SLS rocket has flown only once before, during the uncrewed Artemis I mission in November 2022. The crew will ride in the Orion capsule perched atop the rocket, living in a space roughly the size of a minibus for the duration of the mission, which will conclude with a splashdown in the Pacific Ocean.

Artemis II is designed as the critical precursor to Artemis III, which aims to land astronauts on the lunar surface — the first such landing in more than half a century. NASA has set a target of 2028 for that milestone, though the timeline remains under pressure. SpaceX holds the contract to build the Artemis III lunar lander using its Starship vehicle, but persistent delays have prompted NASA to request an accelerated plan from Elon Musk's company. The agency has also asked Jeff Bezos's Blue Origin to develop a competing fast-track proposal.

The urgency is geopolitical as well as scientific. China is steadily advancing toward its own crewed lunar landing by 2030, with both nations eyeing the Moon's south pole as the prime location for future bases. A successful Artemis II flight would represent a decisive step in reasserting American presence beyond low Earth orbit and set the stage for what promises to be a new era of lunar competition.

articles.headline: New Method Measures Relativistic Thermal States Using Only Stochastic Noise
articles.subheadline: Physicist shows electromagnetic fluctuations alone can reveal a plasma's covariant temperature and velocity — no probes needed
articles.body:
A physicist has proposed the first technique capable of reconstructing the full relativistic thermal state of a fast-moving medium using nothing but the electromagnetic noise it naturally emits — requiring no external probes, spectral lines, or intensity calibration.

Ira Wolfson, in a paper posted to the arXiv preprint server on February 18, demonstrates that the inverse-temperature four-vector β^μ — the quantity that properly describes thermal equilibrium in Einstein's relativity — can be extracted directly from the stochastic electric and magnetic field fluctuations radiated by a drifting plasma. In relativistic physics, temperature is not a simple scalar number but depends on the observer's frame of reference. The four-vector formulation, defined as β^μ = u^μ/(k_B T_0), encodes both the rest-frame temperature and the bulk velocity of the medium in a single covariant object. Wolfson's method exploits the fact that a Lorentz boost transforms isotropic thermal noise in a plasma's rest frame into distinctly correlated electric and magnetic field patterns in a laboratory frame, creating a measurable observable that is independent of detector gain.

The approach relies on the covariant fluctuation-dissipation theorem, which governs how angle-resolved noise spectra relate to the underlying thermodynamic state. By analyzing the directional structure of the emitted noise, the technique first extracts the drift velocity of the plasma purely from stochastic data, then combines this with spectral information to recover the full four-vector. Monte Carlo simulations presented in the paper demonstrate that the method achieves percent-level accuracy at realistic signal-to-noise ratios, with feasibility estimates suggesting that sub-microsecond integration times would suffice for laboratory plasma experiments.

The result bridges several domains of physics — plasma physics, statistical mechanics, and general relativity — and could have practical implications for diagnostics in high-energy-density plasma facilities, astrophysical observations of relativistic jets and accretion flows, and future fusion experiments where relativistic electron populations are present. Passive measurement techniques are particularly valuable in extreme environments where inserting physical probes would be impractical or would disturb the system under study.

Wolfson's paper, spanning four pages with three figures, establishes what the author describes as the first method to reconstruct the covariant thermal state of a relativistic medium from passive electromagnetic fluctuations alone. If validated experimentally, the technique would elevate vacuum electromagnetic noise from a nuisance signal to a precision diagnostic tool for relativistic thermodynamics.

articles.headline: Ancient Oxygen-Breathing Microbes May Explain the Rise of Complex Life
articles.subheadline: A massive genomic study of Asgard archaea resolves a longstanding puzzle about how eukaryotes first emerged
articles.body:
A research team led by the University of Texas at Austin has found compelling evidence that the ancient microbial ancestors of all complex life — including plants, animals, and fungi — were already capable of metabolizing oxygen, resolving a decades-old paradox at the heart of evolutionary biology. The findings, published February 20 in Nature, rewrite assumptions about the conditions under which eukaryotic life first arose.

The origin of eukaryotes is widely understood to have involved a symbiotic merger between two very different microbes: an archaeon and an alphaproteobacterium, which eventually became the mitochondria found inside modern cells. But scientists had long struggled with a contradiction in this model. The alphaproteobacterium required oxygen, while Asgard archaea — the closest known living relatives of the ancestral archaeon — had been found almost exclusively in oxygen-free environments like deep-sea sediments. How, then, could these two partners have met?

The UT Austin team, led by marine scientist Brett Baker, assembled more than 13,000 new microbial genomes from roughly 15 terabytes of environmental DNA collected across multiple marine expeditions, including a December 2025 research cruise off the coast of Uruguay. The effort nearly doubled the known genomic diversity of Asgard archaea and revealed hundreds of previously uncharacterized genomes. Crucially, the researchers identified a subgroup called Heimdallarchaeia — the Asgards most closely related to eukaryotes — living not in anoxic depths but in oxygen-rich shallow coastal sediments and open water columns, equipped with metabolic pathways for oxygen use.

To strengthen the case, the team employed the AI protein-structure prediction tool AlphaFold2 to compare Heimdallarchaeia proteins with those involved in oxygen-based energy production in modern eukaryotic cells. The structural similarities were striking, suggesting that the common ancestor of complex life was already adapted to aerobic metabolism before the fateful symbiotic merger occurred. The timeline also aligns with geological evidence: the earliest known eukaryotic microfossils appear in the fossil record within a few hundred thousand years of the Great Oxidation Event, when atmospheric oxygen levels surged more than 1.7 billion years ago.

"Oxygen appeared in the environment, and Asgards adapted to that. They found an energetic advantage to using oxygen, and then they evolved into eukaryotes," Baker said. The study also doubled the number of recognized enzymatic protein classes within Asgard archaea, opening new avenues for understanding microbial metabolism. Contributors spanned institutions including Monash University, Wageningen University, the Institut Pasteur, and Shandong University, with funding from the Gordon and Betty Moore Foundation, the Simons Foundation, and national science agencies in China and Australia.

articles.headline: Ukrainian Sentenced to Five Years for Helping North Koreans Land U.S. Tech Jobs
articles.subheadline: Oleksandr Didenko handled over 870 stolen American identities through a website that enabled Pyongyang-linked workers to infiltrate dozens of companies
articles.body:
A federal court has sentenced Oleksandr Didenko, a 29-year-old Ukrainian national, to five years in prison for operating an identity theft ring that enabled North Korean workers to fraudulently secure employment at dozens of American companies — funneling wages back to Pyongyang's sanctioned nuclear weapons program.

Didenko, a Kyiv resident, ran a website called Upworksell that sold and rented stolen U.S. identities to overseas workers, including North Koreans seeking remote technical positions at American firms. According to the Department of Justice, Didenko handled more than 870 stolen identities through the platform before the FBI seized it in 2024 and redirected its traffic to government servers. Polish authorities arrested Didenko, who was subsequently extradited to the United States, where he pleaded guilty to the charges originally brought in 2024.

Beyond identity brokering, Didenko also orchestrated so-called "laptop farms" — paying individuals in California, Tennessee, and Virginia to host racks of open laptops in their homes. The setup allowed North Korean operatives to remotely access the machines, making it appear as though they were physically working within the United States. The arrangement is a hallmark of an increasingly sophisticated North Korean IT worker scheme that security researchers have flagged as a growing national security concern.

Cybersecurity firm CrowdStrike reported last year that it has observed a sharp increase in North Korean operatives infiltrating Western companies, typically posing as remote software developers and engineers. Security researchers have characterized these workers as a "triple threat": they violate U.S. sanctions, steal sensitive corporate data, and later extort victim companies by threatening to release proprietary information. The schemes represent one of several revenue streams the North Korean regime relies on to circumvent international financial sanctions, alongside crypto theft and social engineering campaigns targeting high-net-worth individuals.

The sentencing is the latest in a series of convictions tied to Pyongyang's IT worker operations, which U.S. law enforcement has made an enforcement priority. The case underscores the scale of the challenge facing American companies, particularly in the tech sector, where remote hiring practices can be exploited by adversarial state actors operating through intermediaries spread across multiple countries.

articles.headline: Trump Announces 10% Global Tariff Hours After Supreme Court Strikes Down Prior Levies
articles.subheadline: President invokes Section 122 authority to reimpose sweeping trade barriers, reaffirms national security and Section 301 tariffs
articles.body:
President Donald Trump moved swiftly on Friday to reimpose a 10% tariff on all imports into the United States, invoking a different legal authority just hours after the Supreme Court struck down his administration's previous global tariff regime. The new levy, imposed under Section 122 of the Trade Act of 1974, will apply on top of existing duties already in force.

Speaking at a White House press conference, Trump declared that all national security tariffs imposed under Section 232 — which covers steel, aluminum, and other strategically sensitive goods — as well as existing Section 301 tariffs targeting Chinese trade practices, remain in full force and effect. The announcement signals the administration's determination to maintain an aggressive trade posture despite the high court's rebuke.

The Supreme Court's ruling earlier Friday had invalidated the broad global tariffs the Trump administration had previously erected, dealing what many trade analysts viewed as a significant legal blow to the president's trade agenda. But by pivoting to Section 122 — a provision that grants the president authority to impose temporary tariffs of up to 15% for 150 days to address large and serious balance-of-payments deficits — the administration is attempting to preserve much of its tariff architecture under a separate statutory framework.

The legal durability of the new approach remains uncertain. Section 122 has rarely been invoked and carries built-in time constraints that could limit its effectiveness as a long-term trade tool. Legal scholars and trade attorneys are expected to scrutinize whether current economic conditions meet the statute's balance-of-payments threshold, potentially teeing up another round of litigation. The provision was originally designed as an emergency measure, not a foundation for sustained trade policy.

Markets and trading partners now face the prospect of continued tariff uncertainty. The 10% blanket duty, layered on top of the Section 232 and Section 301 tariffs that survived the court's ruling, means effective rates on many imported goods will remain elevated. For major U.S. trading partners — including the European Union, Japan, and South Korea — the rapid reimposition underscores that the administration views tariffs as a central pillar of economic policy, regardless of which legal mechanism underpins them.

articles.headline: Bitcoin Briefly Surges Past $68K After Supreme Court Voids Trump Tariffs
articles.subheadline: Crypto's fleeting rally contrasts with sustained stock gains as stagflationary economic data clouds the outlook
articles.body:
Bitcoin spiked roughly 2% above $68,000 on Friday after the U.S. Supreme Court struck down President Donald Trump's tariff regime in a landmark 6-3 ruling, but the cryptocurrency surrendered those gains within minutes, settling back near $67,000 as sellers once again overwhelmed any hint of upside momentum.

The high court's decision declared that no president had ever invoked the underlying statute to impose tariffs of such "magnitude and scope," concluding that Trump's trade levies extended beyond the executive's "legitimate reach." The ruling sent equities higher in a more durable fashion — the Nasdaq climbed 0.6% to a session high — while Bitcoin's rapid round-trip underscored a persistent pattern in crypto markets, where even modest rallies are met with immediate selling pressure.

Compounding the uncertain macro picture, a batch of economic data released earlier Friday painted a stagflationary portrait of the U.S. economy. The Commerce Department reported that GDP grew just 1.4% in the fourth quarter of 2025, while core personal consumption expenditure prices rose 3% year-over-year, above the consensus forecast of 2.9% and the prior reading of 2.8%. On an annual basis, the economy expanded 2.2% in 2025, the weakest pace since the pandemic year of 2020.

"Today's economic data delivered a messy message of both hotter than expected inflation, and slower than anticipated growth," said Art Hogan, chief market strategist at B. Riley Wealth. He noted that the mixed signals reinforce the Federal Reserve's inclination to proceed cautiously with any changes to monetary policy, a stance that has weighed on risk assets including crypto for much of 2026.

Bitcoin's inability to hold gains on what would ordinarily be considered a bullish catalyst — the removal of tariffs widely blamed for stoking inflation and dampening growth — highlights the fragile sentiment gripping digital asset markets. The leading cryptocurrency has logged its worst performance in the first 50 days of any year on record, and traders appear reluctant to build positions amid persistent macroeconomic headwinds and the Fed's higher-for-longer interest rate posture. At last check, Bitcoin was trading near $67,733, up less than 1% on the day.

articles.headline: New AI Framework Embeds Maxwell's Equations Into Diffusion Models for Photonic Design
articles.subheadline: MxDiffusion outperforms purely data-driven approaches by encoding electromagnetic physics directly into the generative process
articles.body:
A research team spanning Georgia Tech, Oregon State University, and Idaho National Laboratory has unveiled MxDiffusion, a generative AI framework that integrates Maxwell's equations directly into diffusion models to design photonic metasurfaces — marking a significant step toward physics-aware machine learning in nanophotonics.

The framework, detailed in a preprint posted to arXiv on February 18, tackles one of the field's persistent challenges: inverse design, the problem of working backward from desired optical properties to determine the physical structure that produces them. Traditional data-driven AI models can generate plausible designs but often falter when targets fall outside their training data or involve tightly constrained resonance conditions. MxDiffusion addresses this by splitting the generative process into two stages. The first diffusion model is trained with a loss function derived from Maxwell's equations, embedding fundamental electromagnetic constraints into the generation pipeline. The second model then translates this physically consistent intermediate representation into a final structural geometry, achieving what the authors describe as significantly higher fidelity than conventional approaches.

Sujoy Mondal, Taehyuk Park, Sudipta Biswas, Alan X. Wang, and Wenshan Cai validated their framework on two representative test cases: gold nanostructures patterned on silica substrates and a tunable bandpass filter based on phase-change materials. In both scenarios, MxDiffusion consistently outperformed a purely data-driven diffusion model benchmark. The performance gap was most pronounced for out-of-distribution design targets — precisely the regime where data-driven methods tend to break down and where physics-informed constraints provide the greatest advantage.

The work reflects a broader trend in computational physics and engineering toward hybrid approaches that combine the flexibility of modern generative AI with the rigor of established physical laws. Photonic metasurfaces — engineered nanostructures that manipulate light in ways natural materials cannot — are increasingly important for applications ranging from telecommunications filters and sensors to augmented reality displays and LiDAR systems. The ability to rapidly and reliably design these structures from target specifications could accelerate development timelines across multiple industries.

The authors frame MxDiffusion as a general paradigm rather than a solution tailored to specific devices, suggesting the two-stage physics-guided strategy could extend to other domains where physical laws are well characterized but inverse design remains computationally expensive. Whether the approach scales to more complex, multi-objective design problems — and how it compares against other emerging physics-informed neural network architectures — will likely be key questions as the field evaluates its practical impact.

articles.headline: Massive Study Links Air Pollution Directly to Alzheimer's Risk
articles.subheadline: Analysis of 27.8 million Medicare beneficiaries suggests fine particulate matter harms the brain independently of other chronic diseases
articles.body:
Long-term exposure to fine particulate air pollution is associated with a meaningfully higher risk of developing Alzheimer's disease — and the mechanism appears to involve direct damage to the brain rather than indirect pathways through other chronic conditions, according to one of the largest studies ever conducted on the subject.

Published February 17 in the open-access journal PLOS Medicine, the research drew on medical records from more than 27.8 million U.S. Medicare beneficiaries aged 65 and older, tracked between 2000 and 2018. Led by Yanling Deng of Emory University, the team cross-referenced participants' pollution exposure levels with new Alzheimer's diagnoses while controlling for the presence of conditions commonly associated with dementia, including hypertension, stroke, and depression. The central finding: higher pollution exposure corresponded to greater Alzheimer's incidence, and that relationship held even after accounting for these comorbidities — suggesting that airborne fine particles are harming the brain on their own terms.

The study also identified a notable vulnerability among stroke survivors, who showed a somewhat stronger association between pollution exposure and Alzheimer's onset. That finding points to a troubling intersection of environmental and vascular risk factors, where individuals with prior cerebrovascular damage may be less equipped to withstand the neurological toll of polluted air. Hypertension and depression, by contrast, did not appear to amplify the pollution-Alzheimer's connection in any meaningful way.

Alzheimer's disease currently affects an estimated 57 million people worldwide and remains the most prevalent form of dementia. While scientists have long flagged air pollution — particularly fine particulate matter known as PM2.5 — as a risk factor, the question of whether pollution acts on the brain directly or primarily through intermediary conditions had remained unresolved. The Emory team's analysis, funded by the National Institutes of Health, offers some of the strongest evidence to date that the direct pathway dominates.

The implications extend beyond clinical neuroscience into public health policy. If fine particulate pollution is independently driving Alzheimer's risk in aging populations, then stricter air quality standards could serve as a frontline strategy for reducing dementia rates — a prospect that carries particular urgency as the global population ages and air pollution remains stubbornly high in many regions. The authors emphasized that their findings "highlight an important intersection between environmental and vascular risk factors" and underscore the cognitive stakes of the air people breathe every day.

articles.headline: Dubai Opens Secondary Market for Tokenized Real Estate on XRP Ledger
articles.subheadline: The $5 million pilot marks phase two of Dubai's plan to tokenize $16 billion in property by 2033
articles.body:
Dubai's government real estate authority has launched a secondary trading market for blockchain-based property tokens, advancing one of the most ambitious tokenization experiments in the world. The Dubai Land Department (DLD) and infrastructure partner Ctrl Alt announced on Friday that roughly 7.8 million tokens representing fractional ownership in ten Dubai properties — valued at over $5 million — are now eligible for resale on a controlled trading platform.

The tokens, built on Ripple's XRP Ledger and secured through Ripple Custody, are directly backed by title deeds and synced with Dubai's official land registry. A compliance layer using so-called Asset-Referenced Virtual Assets (ARVAs) governs who can trade and under what conditions, ensuring that every transaction is reflected in the emirate's property records. The setup represents a deliberate effort to bridge decentralized blockchain infrastructure with traditional real estate law.

The secondary market launch constitutes the second phase of a pilot that began when the DLD partnered with Ctrl Alt and Prypco to tokenize property deeds on the XRP Ledger. The broader ambition is sweeping: Dubai aims to tokenize 7% of its real estate market — approximately $16 billion worth — by 2033. If successful, the initiative could position the city-state as the global leader in blockchain-based property transactions, where ownership transfers that currently take days or weeks could settle in minutes.

The project arrives at a moment of growing momentum for real-world asset tokenization globally. A Deloitte report published last year projected that $4 trillion in real estate will be tokenized by 2035, implying annual growth of roughly 27%. Yet significant obstacles remain. An EY analysis has noted that uneven regulation across jurisdictions continues to limit adoption, while thin secondary market liquidity — the very problem Dubai's pilot seeks to address — constrains investor interest. In the United States, real estate billionaire Barry Sternlicht has publicly expressed interest in tokenization but cited regulatory barriers as a major impediment.

Dubai's controlled trading environment is designed to test market infrastructure, investor protections, and legal alignment before any broader rollout. While $5 million in tradable property tokens remains a tiny fraction of the emirate's roughly $229 billion real estate market, the pilot's significance lies in what it is proving: that government registries and blockchain settlement can operate in tandem. Whether that model scales to $16 billion will depend on liquidity depth, regulatory durability, and whether investors trust tokens as much as traditional title deeds.

articles.headline: Oil Prices Hold Near Six-Month High Amid Trump's Iran Strike Warning
articles.subheadline: President issues 15-day ultimatum to Tehran over nuclear program as U.S. forces gather in the Middle East
articles.body:
Crude oil prices remained elevated near six-month highs on Thursday after President Donald Trump disclosed he is considering a limited military strike against Iran, injecting fresh geopolitical risk into global energy markets already grappling with tight supply dynamics.

Trump's remarks, in which he warned Tehran it had no more than 15 days to reach an agreement over its nuclear program, came as U.S. military forces were reported gathering in the Middle East. The combination of an explicit ultimatum and visible force posturing sent a clear signal that Washington is prepared to escalate if diplomatic efforts stall. Iran, an OPEC member that produces roughly 3.2 million barrels per day, sits at a critical chokepoint for global oil flows — any disruption to its output or to shipping through the Strait of Hormuz could ripple through markets worldwide.

The threat alone has been sufficient to buoy prices. Oil traders have been pricing in a growing geopolitical risk premium, reflecting the possibility that even a limited strike could trigger retaliatory actions that disrupt regional production or tanker traffic. The Strait of Hormuz, through which approximately 20% of the world's petroleum passes daily, remains the most watched bottleneck in global energy logistics. Market participants are now closely monitoring diplomatic channels for any indication of whether Tehran will engage in negotiations or dig in ahead of the deadline.

The standoff adds another layer of complexity to an oil market already shaped by OPEC+ production management, sanctions enforcement, and shifting demand forecasts. Analysts note that sustained elevated prices could compound inflationary pressures in the United States and Europe at a time when central banks are navigating delicate monetary policy paths. For consumers, a prolonged crisis could translate into higher gasoline and heating costs heading into the spring.

With the 15-day window now ticking, energy markets are likely to remain volatile as traders weigh the probability of a diplomatic resolution against the risk of military action. The coming days will test whether Trump's ultimatum represents a genuine redline or a negotiating tactic designed to force Tehran back to the table.

articles.headline: UK Man Faces 48 Charges for Drugging Wife, Recruiting Men to Assault Her
articles.subheadline: Twelve co-defendants also charged in case spanning decades; trial set for September in Manchester
articles.body:
A man in his sixties from Stockport, Greater Manchester, has been charged with 48 criminal counts for allegedly drugging his wife into unconsciousness and facilitating her sexual assault by multiple men over a period stretching back to the early 2000s.

The husband, who cannot be named for legal reasons, faces charges including conspiracy to rape, sexual assault by penetration, and conspiracy to administer a substance with intent to commit a sexual offence. Twelve other men, ranging in age from 28 to 73, are co-defendants in the case. All 13 appeared at Manchester Minshull Street Crown Court, where seven — including the husband — entered not guilty pleas to all charges. Five defendants were not asked to enter pleas at this stage. One man pleaded guilty to conspiracy to commit rape, conspiracy to administer a substance with intent, conspiracy to commit sexual assault by penetration, and one count of committing sexual assault by penetration.

Members of the woman's family were present in the public gallery during the hearing. The allegations describe a prolonged pattern of abuse in which the victim was rendered unconscious before being subjected to sexual violence by her husband and men he allegedly recruited. The case bears striking similarities to the high-profile French trial of Dominique Pelicot, who was convicted in December 2024 of drugging his wife Gisèle and inviting dozens of strangers to rape her over nearly a decade.

A further hearing is scheduled for March, with a full trial set to begin on September 1. The proceedings are expected to last approximately 12 weeks, reflecting the breadth and complexity of the charges. Greater Manchester Police are leading the investigation.

The case underscores ongoing concerns about drug-facilitated sexual violence within intimate relationships — crimes that experts say remain significantly underreported due to victims being unaware of the abuse while it occurs. Legal observers note that the scale of the alleged conspiracy, involving more than a dozen defendants over two decades, makes it one of the most significant cases of its kind to come before UK courts.

articles.headline: Trade-Linked Stocks Surge After Supreme Court Strikes Down Tariffs
articles.subheadline: Retailers, industrials, and automakers rally sharply as high court rules against Trump's sweeping global trade levies
articles.body:
Shares of trade-sensitive companies across the retail, industrial, and automotive sectors jumped sharply on Friday after the U.S. Supreme Court struck down President Donald Trump's sweeping global tariffs, removing a major overhang that had weighed on corporate earnings outlooks and supply chain planning for months.

The ruling, which invalidated the broad tariff regime Trump had imposed on imports from countries around the world, sent an immediate jolt through equity markets. Retailers — many of which rely heavily on imported consumer goods — were among the biggest beneficiaries, alongside industrial manufacturers and automakers whose complex global supply chains had been disrupted and made more costly by the levies. The decision effectively unwound one of the most consequential trade policy experiments in modern American history, restoring a degree of certainty to businesses that had struggled to price in the unpredictable tariff landscape.

The Supreme Court's intervention marks a dramatic check on executive trade authority and is likely to reshape the legal and political boundaries of presidential power over commerce. While the specifics of the court's reasoning were not immediately detailed, the market's reaction suggested investors had been pricing in at least some probability that the tariffs would remain in place. The swift rally indicated significant pent-up demand for exposure to trade-dependent sectors that had been under pressure.

For retailers, the ruling could translate into lower input costs and improved margins in coming quarters, particularly for companies that source heavily from Asia. Automakers, which had faced the dual burden of higher component costs and retaliatory measures from trading partners, stand to benefit from both reduced expenses and potentially reopened export markets. Industrial firms with sprawling international operations may see relief on both the cost and revenue sides of their ledgers.

The broader implications for U.S. trade policy remain to be seen. The decision could constrain future administrations' ability to impose unilateral tariffs without congressional approval, fundamentally altering the balance of power over trade. Market participants will be closely watching for any legislative response from Capitol Hill, as well as the administration's next moves in the wake of what amounts to a historic judicial rebuke of its economic agenda.

articles.headline: Police Search Former Prince Andrew's Homes After Historic Arrest
articles.subheadline: Andrew Mountbatten-Windsor held for nearly 11 hours on suspicion of sharing confidential trade secrets with Jeffrey Epstein
articles.body:
British police conducted extensive searches of two properties linked to Andrew Mountbatten-Windsor on Friday, one day after the former prince was arrested on suspicion of misconduct in public office — marking the first arrest of a member of the royal family in nearly four centuries.

Thames Valley Police detained the 66-year-old at 8 a.m. Thursday — his birthday — at his temporary residence on King Charles III's Sandringham estate, holding him for nearly 11 hours at a nearby police station before releasing him. Officers have since completed their search of Wood Farm, his current accommodation on the Sandringham grounds, but continued combing through Royal Lodge, the 30-room Windsor residence from which he was evicted earlier this month after his brother stripped him of all royal titles and honors in October. Unmarked vans, believed to be police vehicles, were observed entering the Royal Lodge grounds throughout Friday morning.

The investigation centers on allegations that Mountbatten-Windsor passed confidential government information to the late convicted sex offender Jeffrey Epstein while serving as a U.K. trade envoy. Emails released last month by the U.S. Department of Justice appear to show him forwarding official reports on diplomatic visits to Hong Kong, Vietnam, and Singapore — one sent just five minutes after he received it. A separate communication allegedly contained a confidential brief on investment opportunities tied to reconstruction in Afghanistan's Helmand Province. Mountbatten-Windsor has consistently denied any wrongdoing but has not addressed the most recent allegations stemming from the so-called Epstein files.

Legal experts cautioned that the road to any prosecution remains uncertain. Criminal defense lawyer Sean Caulfield noted that misconduct in public office is "notoriously difficult to prove," beginning with the threshold question of whether Andrew's trade envoy role legally constitutes that of a public officer. The Crown Prosecution Service will ultimately decide whether to bring charges, applying a two-stage test weighing the realistic prospect of conviction and the public interest. Mountbatten-Windsor, who remains eighth in line to the throne, has not been charged.

The arrest represents one of the gravest crises to confront the House of Windsor in its century-long history, drawing comparisons to the abdication of Edward VIII in 1936 and the death of Princess Diana in 1997. It is the first arrest of a royal since King Charles I, whose detention precipitated the English Civil War and his eventual execution. King Charles III issued a brief statement saying "the law must take its course" but declined further comment. Separately, police forces across the U.K. are conducting their own investigations into Epstein's ties to Britain, including reviews of flight logs at multiple airports. The trafficking allegations previously made by the late Virginia Giuffre were not part of Thursday's arrest, though they remain under separate review.

articles.headline: U.S. Military Buildup Near Iran Reaches Critical Mass as Second Carrier Deploys
articles.subheadline: Pentagon positions forces capable of sustained bombing campaign while Trump remains noncommittal on use of force
articles.body:
The United States has amassed military assets in the Middle East sufficient to sustain a weeks-long bombing campaign against Iran, with a second aircraft carrier moving into the Mediterranean and 50 additional fighter jets arriving in the region, according to NPR reporting on February 20.

The buildup significantly exceeds what military analysts say would be needed simply to pressure Tehran during nuclear negotiations, raising questions about the administration's endgame. President Trump has declined to specify his objectives but has demanded that Iran effectively dismantle its nuclear program and make additional concessions — terms Tehran has historically rejected. Alex Vatanka, an Iran expert at the Middle East Institute, told NPR that Iranian leadership anticipates a military conflict with the United States larger than last summer's 12-day war with Israel, though not on the scale of the 2003 Iraq invasion.

The military escalation comes as Trump simultaneously pursues an expansive diplomatic agenda through his newly created Board of Peace, which held its inaugural meeting on February 19. The administration used the occasion to unveil ambitious development plans for Gaza's coastline, including high-end condominiums and skyscrapers. Trump announced that member states have pledged $7 billion for Gaza's reconstruction, with the United States committing an additional $10 billion. The board, initially formed to oversee the Gaza ceasefire, is being positioned as a vehicle for addressing multiple global conflicts — a scope that has alarmed some world leaders who fear it could sideline the United Nations. Critics warn that the world's most powerful nation establishing an alternative multilateral framework threatens to undermine the U.N.'s role as a platform where smaller countries participate in international decision-making.

The dual developments — military brinkmanship with Iran and a bold reimagining of postwar Gaza — underscore the administration's willingness to reshape Middle Eastern geopolitics through both hard and soft power simultaneously. With Iran showing no signs of capitulating to American demands and the Board of Peace generating international unease, the coming weeks could prove pivotal for regional stability and the broader international order. The situation also arrives against the backdrop of significant domestic and allied tensions, including the unprecedented arrest of King Charles' brother Andrew Mountbatten-Windsor on suspicion of sharing sensitive government information, which British authorities continue to investigate.

articles.headline: Two Teenagers Sentenced to Life for Racist Murder in South Wales
articles.subheadline: Kamran Aman, 38, was stabbed through the heart while delivering groceries to his mother's home in Barry
articles.body:
Two teenagers have been sentenced to life in prison for the racially motivated murder of Kamran Aman, a 38-year-old father who was attacked without provocation while delivering food to his mother's home in Barry, south Wales. Marcus Staniforth, 17, received a minimum term of 17 years, while a second defendant, 16, who cannot be named for legal reasons, was given a minimum of 15 years at Cardiff Crown Court.

The attack occurred just before midnight on June 30, when Aman parked his car a few doors from his mother's house on Barry Road after spending the day working and the evening with his wife and four-year-old daughter. The younger defendant, looking down from a bedroom window after hours of drinking, spotted Aman in his car and decided to attack him. After hurling racist abuse and attempting to enter the vehicle, the 16-year-old began punching Aman as he exited the car, with Staniforth quickly joining the assault. Witnesses described the beating as "relentless," likening the attackers to a "pack of animals." Staniforth then ran into a nearby house, returning 15 seconds later with a large kitchen knife that he swung "multiple times," stabbing Aman once through the heart.

Aman managed to reach a neighbor's doorway, telling her "I think I've been stabbed" and "I can't breathe" as blood pooled on the floor. Even as the victim lay dying, the younger defendant bent over him shouting racist abuse. South Wales Police said Aman suffered "abhorrent racist abuse before, during and after" the assault. Staniforth attempted to destroy evidence by washing the knife and his hands with bleach, but both teenagers were arrested roughly 10 minutes later. His DNA was found on the weapon, and Aman's blood was recovered from Staniforth's shorts and the other defendant's shoes.

Judge Mr. Justice Griffiths called Staniforth a "very dangerous man indeed," telling him he had "turned a failing attempt at beating a man into murder." Addressing the younger defendant, the judge said he had "instigated a deliberate, unprovoked, sustained, violent racist attack" and was "old enough to know that to cause serious injury on a stranger because of his race was wrong." Defense counsel argued the 16-year-old suffered from autism spectrum disorder and ADHD that affected his emotional maturity, and that he had not known Staniforth would bring a knife. The court was not persuaded to significantly reduce the sentence.

Aman's wife, Khaleela James, told the court their daughter is now "traumatised" by her father's death and suffers from separation anxiety, fearing her mother will also not come home. "There is a hole in our heart that can never be filled," she said, addressing the defendants, who showed no emotion. Aman's mother, Shahnaz Aman, said her surviving family members are now "terrified" and no longer visit Barry. Aliya Mohammed, CEO of Race Equality First, said the court's explicit recognition of the racial motive sends "an important message that racism has been taken seriously by the courts," adding that racist violence harms entire communities beyond the immediate victim.

articles.headline: UK Athletics Pleads Guilty to Corporate Manslaughter of Paralympian
articles.subheadline: Abdullah Hayayei, a UAE father of five, was killed when a metal cage collapsed on him during training in 2017
articles.body:
UK Athletics, the governing body for track and field in Britain, reversed its earlier plea on Friday and admitted guilt to the corporate manslaughter of Paralympian Abdullah Hayayei, who was killed during a training session in London nearly eight years ago.

Hayayei, a 36-year-old thrower from the United Arab Emirates and father of five, died in July 2017 when a metal cage fell on him at Newham Leisure Centre. He had been preparing for the World Para-athletics Championships in London, where he was due to compete in the F34 shot put, discus, and javelin events. The athlete had made his Paralympic debut at Rio 2016, finishing sixth in the javelin and seventh in the shot put, and had previously represented his country at the 2015 World Championships in Doha.

The guilty plea, entered at the Old Bailey, marks a dramatic reversal from March 2025, when UK Athletics had denied the charge. Keith Davies, 78, who served as head of sport for the 2017 World Para-athletics Championships, also changed his plea on Friday, admitting to a health and safety offense after previously denying gross negligence manslaughter. Prosecutor Karen Robinson told the court that a two-day sentencing hearing would be scheduled for early June, and that the prosecution would not pursue a trial. Outstanding charges against both defendants will be resolved at sentencing. Davies was granted continued bail on the condition that he cooperate with the Probation Service for a pre-sentence report.

The case has drawn renewed attention to safety standards at major international athletics events. Hayayei's death cast a shadow over the 2017 World Para-athletics Championships, where a moment of silence was held in his honor during the opening ceremony at London Stadium. The lengthy legal proceedings — spanning nearly eight years from the incident to a guilty plea — underscore the complexity of corporate manslaughter prosecutions in the United Kingdom, which require proof that senior management failures caused a death.

UK Athletics now faces what could be a substantial financial penalty at sentencing. Under English law, corporate manslaughter convictions carry unlimited fines, with courts directed to consider the severity of the management failure and the organization's financial resources. The sentencing hearing in June will determine the consequences for both the governing body and Davies personally.

articles.headline: Eric Dane, Grey's Anatomy and Euphoria Star, Dies at 53
articles.subheadline: The actor spent his final months as a tireless advocate for ALS research after revealing his diagnosis in April 2025
articles.body:
Eric Dane, the actor beloved for his roles as "Dr. McSteamy" on Grey's Anatomy and the troubled patriarch Cal Jacobs on HBO's Euphoria, died Thursday afternoon following a battle with amyotrophic lateral sclerosis. He was 53 years old, and had lived less than a year since publicly disclosing his diagnosis.

Dane's family confirmed his death in a statement, saying he spent his final days surrounded by his wife, actress and model Rebecca Gayheart, and their two daughters, Billie and Georgia, who were "the center of his world." Born in San Francisco in 1972, Dane built a career spanning more than three decades, beginning with a television debut on The Wonder Years in 1993. He went on to appear in Charmed, The Last Ship, and films including Marley & Me and Burlesque, but it was his 2006 arrival on Grey's Anatomy as the charismatic plastic surgeon Dr. Mark Sloan that made him a household name.

In the ten months between his April 2025 diagnosis and his death, Dane channeled his public profile into an urgent campaign for ALS awareness and research funding. He joined the board of directors of Target ALS in December and helped one of its fundraising campaigns surpass $500,000. Earlier this month, Time magazine named him among its 100 most influential people in health. "I'm trying to save my life," he told the publication, "and if my actions can move the needle forward for myself and countless others, I'm satisfied." In November, he took on a role in NBC's Brilliant Minds portraying a firefighter grappling with an ALS diagnosis — art mirroring his own reality.

Tributes poured in from across Hollywood. Patrick Dempsey, his longtime Grey's Anatomy co-star, called him "the funniest man" and "wickedly intelligent," praising both his on-set humor and his advocacy work. Euphoria creator Sam Levinson described working with Dane as "an honor" and his friendship as "a gift." Ashton Kutcher urged fans to "keep fighting the fight to solve ALS," while actress Nina Dobrev said Dane "led with kindness and made everyone on our set feel seen."

Dane had spoken candidly about the emotional weight of his illness, telling Good Morning America in June that the diagnosis made him "angry" — particularly because he had lost his own father to suicide as a child and feared his daughters would lose him while they were still young. ALS, also known as Lou Gehrig's disease, is a progressive neurodegenerative condition with no cure. According to the Muscular Dystrophy Association, most patients survive three to five years after diagnosis, though Dane's decline was notably swift. His family asked that his memory continue to fuel the research and awareness he championed until the end.

articles.headline: Israeli Settlers Kill 19-Year-Old Palestinian American in West Bank
articles.subheadline: Nasrallah Abu Siyam is the second U.S. citizen killed by settlers in under a year as West Bank violence escalates
articles.body:
Israeli settlers shot and killed Nasrallah Abu Siyam, a 19-year-old Palestinian American, during an attack on the West Bank village of Mukhmas on Wednesday, according to the Palestinian Health Ministry and eyewitnesses. The killing marks the first Palestinian death at the hands of settlers in 2026 and the second fatal shooting of a U.S. citizen by settlers in less than a year.

According to village resident Raed Abu Ali, a group of settlers descended on Mukhmas — located east of Ramallah — on Wednesday afternoon, assaulting a farmer and triggering clashes when villagers intervened. Israeli military forces subsequently arrived and deployed tear gas, sound grenades, and live ammunition, Abu Ali said. He described armed settlers opening fire after soldiers appeared on the scene, killing Abu Siyam and injuring several others. "When the settlers saw the army, they were encouraged and started shooting live bullets," Abu Ali told the Associated Press, adding that settlers beat wounded Palestinians with sticks as they lay on the ground.

The Israeli military acknowledged using "riot dispersal methods" after receiving reports of rock-throwing but denied its forces fired during the confrontation. It confirmed that unnamed suspects had shot at Palestinians, who were evacuated for medical treatment. The military did not indicate whether any arrests were made. A U.S. Embassy spokesperson said they "condemn this violence," though offered no further detail.

The incident comes amid a sustained escalation in the occupied West Bank. Israeli forces and settlers killed 240 Palestinians in 2025, according to the United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs, while Palestinians killed 17 Israelis — six of them soldiers — over the same period. The Palestinian Authority's Wall and Settlement Resistance Commission identified Abu Siyam as the first settler-related fatality of the new year. Mukhmas and its surrounding area, most of which falls under Israeli civil and military administration, have become a focal point for settler violence, including arson, physical assaults, and the construction of outposts deemed illegal even under Israeli law.

The killing coincided with a sweeping report from the U.N. High Commissioner for Human Rights accusing Israel of war crimes in the West Bank and warning that the forced displacement of Palestinians and demographic alterations to the territory "raise concerns over ethnic cleansing." The office cited a "concerted and accelerating effort to consolidate annexation" based on findings from November 2024 through October 2025. Palestinian rights advocates and human rights organizations have long charged that Israeli authorities routinely fail to prosecute settlers or hold them accountable, a pattern they say emboldens further violence. Israel has repeatedly rejected allegations of bias from U.N. bodies.

articles.headline: Taliban Escalates Enforcement of Women's Dress Code in Afghan City of Herat
articles.subheadline: Hospital admissions dropped 28% as vice agents blocked women without burkas from accessing healthcare and transport
articles.body:
Taliban authorities have intensified enforcement of strict dress codes for women and girls in the western Afghan city of Herat since November, deploying agents at hospitals, schools, and transport checkpoints to bar those who show their faces in public, according to interviews with more than a dozen residents and reports from international organizations.

The crackdown, led by officials from the Ministry for the Promotion of Virtue and Prevention of Vice, initially required women to wear the full Afghan burka — a blue garment with a netted eye opening — before entering government buildings and health facilities. At Herat Regional Hospital, the consequences were immediate and severe. Female staff were forced to wait outside for hours, exchanging burkas with colleagues ending night shifts like tokens granting "entry permission," according to a male medic who spoke to NPR on condition of anonymity. Doctors Without Borders reported a 28% drop in urgent admissions during the first days of enforcement, though numbers recovered after the initial shock. Human Rights Watch documented the detention of a female surgeon for several hours for failing to wear a burka.

Facing resistance, authorities partially relented. After what residents described as sustained pushback — including an incident in which dozens of teenage girls physically overwhelmed vice agents posted outside a religious seminary — officials eased requirements to allow women to wear the traditional chaddar cloak with a face mask. The seminary confrontation saw girls refuse to enter the school, telling Taliban officials to "either repeal this law or we will not enter." They were ultimately allowed in without burkas but were ordered to wear black niqabs and gloves.

The enforcement extended to public transport, where agents set up checkpoints to inspect women's clothing inside vehicles. Women were first ordered to sit only in the back of shared minibuses, then banned from riding alongside men entirely. The segregation tripled fares for women — from roughly 50 cents to $1.60 per ride — and some drivers refused to carry female passengers at all due to checkpoint delays. Two female health workers told NPR they witnessed agents detaining women inside a shipping container in a Herat square for hours in freezing November temperatures, their offense being the wearing of headscarves and long coats without a chaddar.

The restrictions trace back to a May 2022 edict requiring post-pubescent women to wear either a burka or a full black robe with face veil and gloves, with male guardians held responsible for compliance. A more detailed law followed in August 2024. Sahar Fetrat of Human Rights Watch called the policies part of the Taliban's effort "to make women invisible," noting that Afghan women and United Nations experts have labeled the system "gender apartheid." Kate Clark of the Afghanistan Analysts Network observed that enforcement "moves in waves" driven by unpredictable factors, from changes in local leadership to public backlash. The Taliban did not respond to requests for comment.

articles.headline: Prince Andrew's Arrest Poses Unprecedented Crisis for British Monarchy
articles.subheadline: King Charles pledges 'full and wholehearted' cooperation as his brother is detained on suspicion of misconduct in public office
articles.body:
The arrest of Andrew Mountbatten-Windsor — the former Prince Andrew — on suspicion of misconduct in public office has plunged the British monarchy into what may be its most acute institutional crisis in a generation, forcing King Charles III into the extraordinary position of publicly distancing himself from his own brother while pledging full cooperation with investigators.

Andrew was taken from his residence on the King's Sandringham estate in Norfolk, photographed, fingerprinted, and held for approximately 11 hours at Aylsham Police Investigation Centre before being released under investigation. In a carefully worded statement issued hours after the arrest, the King expressed his "deepest concern" about "Andrew Mountbatten-Windsor and suspicion of misconduct in public office," notably using his brother's legal surname rather than any royal title and making no reference to their familial bond. The authorities, Charles wrote, "have our full and wholehearted support and cooperation."

The arrest caps a dramatic fall for a man who, just months ago, appeared publicly with the royal family at the funeral of the Duchess of Kent at Westminster Cathedral and who for years used Buckingham Palace as the backdrop for his investment initiative, Pitch@Palace. Royal supporters have pointed to the unprecedented steps Charles has already taken — stripping Andrew of his titles, removing him from Royal Lodge, and offering assistance to investigators — as evidence of decisive leadership. Jonathan Dimbleby, the King's biographer and friend, argued on BBC Radio 4's World at One that the arrest need not damage the monarchy itself. "I think we have to separate the notion of a family from the institution of the monarchy," Dimbleby said.

That distinction, however, is one the broader public may not readily accept. Andrew remains in the line of succession to the Crown, and his decades as a working royal make any claim that his legal troubles are a "private matter" difficult to sustain. The Palace has long maintained a boundary between members' public duties and personal lives, but critics argue the institution was too slow to act as allegations accumulated over years — particularly those connected to the Jeffrey Epstein scandal. New Mexico has separately reopened a criminal inquiry into Epstein's Zorro Ranch property, and newly released files suggest the financier sought record-label investments as a means of accessing women, raising the prospect of further revelations.

For King Charles, the challenge is existential in nature: a hereditary monarchy derives its legitimacy from bloodline, yet that very bloodline now ties the Crown to a criminal investigation. The Palace has signaled it will not seek any special treatment for the former prince, but the unanswered question looming over the institution is how much more damaging information the promised "wholehearted" cooperation might ultimately surface.

articles.headline: Trump Sets 15-Day Deadline for Iran Nuclear Deal as U.S. Surges Forces to Region
articles.subheadline: A second aircraft carrier approaches the Middle East while Iran conducts joint military drills with Russia, raising fears of imminent conflict.
articles.body:
President Donald Trump issued a stark warning to Iran on Thursday, declaring that 10 to 15 days should be "enough time" to reach a nuclear agreement and that "bad things happen" if a meaningful deal cannot be struck — even as the United States deployed a second aircraft carrier toward the Middle East and Iran staged joint naval exercises with Russia.

The escalation marks the most dangerous moment in U.S.-Iran relations since American and Israeli strikes hit Iranian nuclear sites and military installations last summer. According to a senior U.S. official speaking on condition of anonymity, top national security officials met Wednesday and were briefed that the "full forces" required to execute potential military action against Iran are expected to be in position by mid-March. An additional 50 U.S. combat aircraft — including F-35s, F-22s, and F-16s — were ordered to the region this week alone, joining hundreds already stationed at bases across the Arab Gulf states.

Diplomatic channels remain open but fragile. Iran has agreed to draft a written proposal addressing American concerns raised during indirect nuclear talks in Geneva this week, though no timeline for delivery has been disclosed. The negotiations face a fundamental impasse: Washington and Israel want Iran to curtail its ballistic missile program and cut ties with proxy groups like Hamas and Hezbollah, while Tehran insists discussions must focus solely on nuclear matters. Iran's ambassador to the United Nations, Amir Saeid Iravani, warned in a letter to the Security Council that any U.S. aggression would be met "decisively and proportionately," and that all American bases and assets in the region would become "legitimate targets."

The military posturing is intensifying on all sides. The USS Gerald R. Ford carrier strike group was tracked off the coast of Morocco on Wednesday, headed toward the Mediterranean, while Iranian and Russian forces conducted drills in the Gulf of Oman and Indian Ocean. Iran also carried out live-fire exercises in the Strait of Hormuz, through which roughly one-fifth of the world's traded oil transits. Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu declared his country "prepared for any scenario," warning that any Iranian attack on Israel would provoke a response Tehran "cannot even imagine." Polish Prime Minister Donald Tusk urged his citizens to leave Iran immediately, warning that evacuation could become impossible within hours, while Germany began withdrawing non-essential military personnel from northern Iraq.

A senior regional government official who has been in private contact with Iranian leaders said he has urged Tehran to take Trump's threats at face value, pointing to the president's track record of following through on rhetoric. The official cautioned, however, that a limited U.S. strike intended to pressure Iran could backfire, potentially prompting Supreme Leader Ali Khamenei to abandon negotiations entirely. Iran's theocratic government is already under severe strain, facing mass anti-government protests that were violently suppressed in January, with mourners still holding memorial ceremonies for slain demonstrators 40 days later.

articles.headline: Epstein Eyed EMI Records Deal to Access Women, DOJ Files Reveal
articles.subheadline: Newly released emails show convicted sex offender's associate pitched music industry investment as offering access to 'P'
articles.body:
Newly released U.S. Department of Justice files reveal that convicted sex offender Jeffrey Epstein considered investing in troubled music conglomerate EMI after an associate suggested the deal could offer access to women, adding another disturbing dimension to the financier's pattern of leveraging business ventures for predatory purposes.

The emails, part of a tranche of Epstein files released by the DOJ, show London-based German businessman David Stern forwarding a news article about EMI's financial difficulties in February 2010 with the note: "Troubled industry but related to P." The letter "P" was Epstein's habitual shorthand for women, believed to abbreviate a vulgar term he frequently used. Stern routinely employed the code in correspondence — wishing Epstein "lots of P" on birthdays, rating destinations by "P factor" (Ibiza received 9 out of 10), and once offering fashion show tickets "to review Chinese P."

Epstein responded to the EMI pitch with apparent interest, asking whether they needed help from "mandelson" — an apparent reference to Lord Mandelson, who at the time served as Britain's First Secretary of State and Business Secretary. Stern advised it was "too early to get Mandelson involved." Days later, Epstein appears to have emailed Lord Mandelson directly requesting a contact's information regarding EMI. Lord Mandelson appears to have responded with contact details, though portions of the exchange were redacted. Neither Stern nor Lord Mandelson responded to requests for comment.

The proposed acquisition never materialized. Epstein suggested installing Tommy Mottola, the former Sony Music CEO, to run the operation, writing that he wanted Mottola "brought in to fix it." Mottola's name appears more than 700 times across the DOJ files, though an appearance in the documents is not an indication of wrongdoing. Mottola did not respond to a request for comment. EMI's main lender, Citigroup, ultimately seized control of the company and later sold it to Universal Music and a Sony-led consortium in 2012.

The EMI episode was not an isolated case. As late as 2011, Stern was still pushing the idea, writing that the company "could actually be of interest to Chinese if structured properly" and was "most certainly great asset to have for P!" The DOJ files also document discussions among Epstein and his associates about acquiring modeling agencies and fashion-related businesses — none of which went forward. French prosecutors previously suspected that Epstein used fashion industry contacts, including the late Jean-Luc Brunel, to house and transport underage girls. Stern, who had close ties to Andrew Mountbatten-Windsor and directed the former prince's Pitch@Palace startup competition, also served as an intermediary in negotiations involving Sarah Ferguson's finances, underscoring the breadth of Epstein's network across business, politics, and royalty.

articles.headline: Stanford Team Develops 'Universal Vaccine' Targeting All Respiratory Infections
articles.subheadline: Nasal spray approach represents a 'radical departure' from 200 years of vaccine design, but human trials are still needed
articles.body:
Researchers at Stanford University have developed an experimental nasal spray vaccine that could protect against virtually all respiratory viruses, multiple bacterial infections, and even allergens — a fundamentally new approach to immunization that the team says breaks from over two centuries of vaccine design.

Published in the journal Science, the study demonstrated that the vaccine produced a 100- to 1,000-fold reduction in viruses penetrating the lungs of animal subjects. Unlike conventional vaccines, which train the immune system to recognize a specific pathogen, the Stanford approach works by placing immune cells called macrophages in the lungs on a state of heightened readiness — what the researchers describe as an "amber alert" — enabling them to respond rapidly to any invading pathogen. The effect persisted for approximately three months in animal experiments. Professor Bali Pulendran, a microbiologist and immunologist at Stanford who led the work, said the vaccine elicits "a far broader response that is protective against not just the flu virus, not just the Covid virus, not just the common cold virus, but against virtually all viruses, and as many different bacteria as we've tested, and even allergens."

The research showed efficacy against two dangerous bacterial species — Staphylococcus aureus and Acinetobacter baumannii — and appeared to reduce immune responses to house dust mite allergens, a common trigger of allergic asthma. Professor Daniela Ferreira, a vaccinologist at the University of Oxford who was not involved in the study, called it "a really exciting piece of research" that "could mark a major step forward" in protecting people from the heavy burden of respiratory infections.

Significant hurdles remain before the technology reaches patients. No human clinical trials have been conducted, and researchers acknowledge key uncertainties: whether the same immune priming can be achieved in people, how long the protective state would last, and whether artificially elevating the immune system's baseline vigilance could trigger harmful side effects. Jonathan Ball, professor of molecular virology at the Liverpool School of Tropical Medicine, cautioned that keeping the body on "high alert" risks "friendly fire, where a hyper-ready immune system accidentally triggers unwelcome side effects." The delivery method may also need to change — while tested as a nasal spray in animals, a nebulizer might be required to reach the deeper regions of human lungs.

The Stanford team envisions the universal vaccine as a complement to existing immunizations rather than a replacement. In a pandemic scenario similar to early 2020, such a vaccine could buy critical time while pathogen-specific vaccines are developed. More routinely, Pulendran suggested, a seasonal spray administered at the onset of winter could "imprint broad immunity" against the constellation of respiratory bugs that circulate each year. The researchers are now planning human challenge trials in which vaccinated volunteers would be deliberately exposed to infections to evaluate the approach's real-world potential.

articles.headline: Venezuela Signs Amnesty Law That Could Free Hundreds of Political Prisoners
articles.subheadline: The landmark measure marks a dramatic reversal for a government that long denied holding anyone for political reasons
articles.body:
Venezuela's acting president Delcy Rodríguez signed an amnesty bill into law on Thursday that could lead to the release of hundreds of politicians, activists, journalists, and human rights defenders imprisoned under the now-deposed government of Nicolás Maduro — a sweeping acknowledgment that the state has for years jailed citizens on political grounds.

The legislation, approved by Venezuela's National Assembly just hours before Rodríguez signed it, grants "general and full amnesty" for politically motivated crimes and offenses committed during specific periods dating back to 1999. The law covers acts connected to political conflicts, including the contested 2024 presidential election and its aftermath, which triggered mass protests and the arrest of more than 2,000 people, among them minors. Rodríguez, who proposed the bill in late January, said during the signing ceremony that the measure showed the country's leaders were "letting go of a little intolerance and opening new avenues for politics in Venezuela."

The amnesty represents the most significant policy shift yet in a country undergoing rapid transformation following last month's U.S. military raid on Caracas that resulted in Maduro's capture. Since then, Rodríguez's transitional government has moved quickly to comply with demands from the Trump administration, including an overhaul of Venezuela's oil industry law. The amnesty bill, however, did not come without friction. Debate was suspended last week after ruling-party loyalists clashed with other lawmakers over whether Venezuelans who fled the country to avoid detention should qualify for relief. The compromise reached Thursday allows exiles to have a lawyer petition for amnesty on their behalf without requiring them to return.

Prisoners' rights organization Foro Penal estimates that more than 600 people remain in custody for political reasons. While the government pledged mass releases after Maduro's fall, only 448 prisoners have been freed so far, according to Foro Penal's tally. Families of the detained have been gathering outside prisons for days, with some launching a hunger strike on Saturday to pressure authorities. Opposition lawmaker Nora Bracho acknowledged the bill's limitations during the legislative debate but called it "a great step forward" that "will alleviate the suffering of many Venezuelans."

Human rights groups and opposition figures have greeted the measure with cautious optimism, noting that amnesty has been a central demand for years. The law's real test will come in its implementation — whether the government follows through on releasing prisoners swiftly and whether eligibility criteria are applied fairly across the broad spectrum of those detained under Maduro's two-decade rule.

articles.headline: A Remote Russian Village Has Lost Nearly All Its Fighting-Age Men to War
articles.subheadline: BBC analysis reveals indigenous communities and rural poor bear devastating, disproportionate burden of Russia's mounting casualties in Ukraine
articles.body:
In the remote fishing village of Sedanka on Russia's Kamchatka Peninsula — more than 7,000 kilometers from the front lines in Ukraine — nearly every man between the ages of 18 and 55 has left to fight in Moscow's war. Of the 39 who signed military contracts from a population of just 258, twelve have been confirmed killed and seven more are missing, leaving a community of women, children, and elderly struggling to survive winters that plunge to minus 10 degrees Celsius without anyone to chop firewood for their stoves.

The devastation visited upon Sedanka, home primarily to the indigenous Koryak and Itelmen peoples, is emblematic of a broader pattern revealed by an extensive BBC and Medizona casualty analysis. The investigation has now identified 186,102 Russian soldiers killed by name, with confirmed 2024 deaths reaching 69,362 — roughly equal to the combined totals for 2022 and 2023. The researchers estimate that 2025 is on pace to be the deadliest year yet for Russian forces, with total deaths projected to reach 80,000. Military experts believe the verified figures may represent only 45 to 65 percent of actual losses, placing the true Russian death toll somewhere between 286,000 and 413,500.

The burden of these casualties falls with stark inequality across Russian society. According to the analysis, 67 percent of confirmed dead came from rural areas and towns with populations under 100,000, despite such areas accounting for only 48 percent of Russia's population. Moscow, the nation's wealthiest city, has recorded the lowest per-capita death rate at just 0.05 percent of military-age males. By contrast, impoverished regions like Buryatia and Tuva in Siberia suffer death rates 27 to 33 times higher than the capital. Indigenous groups are hit hardest of all: confirmed losses include an estimated 2 percent of all Chukchi men aged 18 to 60, 1.4 percent of Russian Inuit men, and 1.32 percent of Koryak men.

Demographers point to economic desperation as the primary driver. "For many, the driver is not only poverty but a lack of prospects — the feeling that there is nothing to lose," one Russian demographer told the BBC. Anti-war activist Maria Vyushkova accused the Kremlin of exploiting indigenous cultural pride, noting that state television promotes stereotypes of indigenous peoples as "born warriors" to boost recruitment. In Sedanka, one such recruit was Vladimir Akeev, a 45-year-old hunter and fisherman who signed his army contract in the summer of 2024 and was killed in combat four months later. His coffin was carried to the cemetery on wooden sleds pulled by snowmobile.

The Russian government has offered Sedanka little beyond symbolism. A monument to war participants was unveiled in the village last autumn, and regional authorities pledged an honorary title of "village of military valour" along with a family support program — neither of which has materialized in full. The village's sole school has been declared in a state of emergency, with walls at risk of collapse, and one in five Soviet-era homes have been deemed unsafe. Ukraine has also sustained severe losses, with President Volodymyr Zelensky citing 55,000 official battlefield deaths and a large number of missing; independent estimates suggest the true Ukrainian toll may approach 200,000. As peace talks in Geneva struggle to produce a breakthrough, the human cost continues to mount — felt most acutely in places the world has barely heard of.

articles.headline: Hamas Holds Internal Election to Choose New Interim Leader
articles.subheadline: The vote, conducted across Gaza, the West Bank, and abroad, pits veteran Khaled Meshaal against Gaza-aligned Khalil al-Hayya
articles.body:
Hamas is conducting an internal election to select a new interim leader, a senior Palestinian official with knowledge of the group's affairs told the BBC, marking the most significant leadership decision since Israeli forces killed the group's top figures over the past two years.

Voting is underway across Gaza, the occupied West Bank, and among Hamas members based abroad, with ballots in Gaza reportedly already cast in secret. The winner will serve a one-year term. The contest is widely seen as a two-person race between Khaled Meshaal, the Qatar-based veteran who led Hamas for nearly two decades, and Khalil al-Hayya, the group's senior figure in Gaza who is considered ideologically close to the late Yahya Sinwar. Under Hamas's rules, the leader is chosen by an electoral college of roughly 86 members drawn from the General Shura Council, the movement's top decision-making body.

The election carries outsized significance for the trajectory of both Hamas and the broader Israeli-Palestinian conflict. Since the October 7, 2023 attacks on Israel — which killed approximately 1,200 people and saw 251 taken hostage — Israel has systematically dismantled Hamas's senior leadership. Sinwar, the group's overall head, was killed by Israeli forces in Gaza in October 2024. Political chief Ismail Haniyeh was assassinated in an Israeli strike in Tehran in July 2024. Military commander Mohammed Deif was killed in a Gaza airstrike that same month. Since then, an interim committee led by Qatar-based Mohammad Darwish has guided the organization, but the top post has remained formally vacant.

The outcome could signal which of Hamas's competing internal currents will dominate going forward. Meshaal represents what observers describe as the group's more pragmatic, Muslim Brotherhood-aligned wing, while al-Hayya is associated with the Iran-aligned faction that held sway during Sinwar's tenure. The devastating war in Gaza — which has killed more than 72,000 people according to the Hamas-run health ministry — has weakened the territory-based leadership and reopened space for the so-called "old guard" linked to Meshaal. Hamas's 18-member political leadership is evenly split among Gaza, the West Bank and prisoners, and the diaspora, giving external figures considerable weight in the current environment.

The leadership question also has direct implications for ceasefire negotiations and post-war governance. A U.S.-backed ceasefire took effect in October, with talks continuing over subsequent phases. Under Washington's proposed framework, Hamas would have no role in governing Gaza, with authority eventually transferring to a reformed Palestinian Authority. Yet recent reports indicate Hamas has already begun reasserting control over security, taxation, and government services in the territory — a reality that any new leader will need to navigate against mounting internal pressures and an uncertain geopolitical landscape.

articles.headline: Google Launches Gemini 3.1 Pro With Doubled Reasoning Performance
articles.subheadline: The upgraded AI model scores 77.1% on ARC-AGI-2 benchmark, rolling out across developer, enterprise, and consumer platforms
articles.body:
Google unveiled Gemini 3.1 Pro on Wednesday, an upgraded AI model that the company says more than doubles the reasoning performance of its predecessor on key benchmarks. The release marks the latest salvo in an intensifying race among tech giants to build increasingly capable AI systems.

The new model achieved a verified score of 77.1% on ARC-AGI-2, a benchmark that tests a model's ability to solve novel logic patterns it has never encountered before. Google says this represents more than twice the reasoning capability of Gemini 3 Pro, which launched in November 2025. The improvement signals meaningful progress in the kind of abstract problem-solving that has historically challenged large language models, moving beyond pattern-matching on familiar tasks toward genuine logical inference.

Gemini 3.1 Pro is rolling out across Google's ecosystem simultaneously — available to developers in preview through the Gemini API in Google AI Studio, Gemini CLI, and Google's agentic development platform Antigravity, as well as Android Studio. Enterprise customers can access it through Vertex AI and Gemini Enterprise, while consumers will find it in the Gemini app and NotebookLM. The broad deployment underscores Google's strategy of threading its most advanced AI capabilities through every layer of its product stack, from cloud infrastructure to consumer applications.

Google highlighted several practical demonstrations of the model's capabilities, emphasizing tasks that go well beyond simple question-and-answer interactions. In one example, 3.1 Pro built a live aerospace dashboard that configured a public telemetry stream to visualize the International Space Station's orbit.
